message: The bug that's been eluding you for three days will be solved when a freshman points out an unnecessary semicolon in your demo code.
Your next Git commit message will become a legendary meme in Stack Overflow discussions about documentation best practices.
The student who always sits in the back of your Data Structures class will optimize your sorting algorithm in a way you never considered.
That old Python script you wrote in grad school will suddenly become relevant when quantum computing meets machine learning.
Your most confusing recursion explanation will unexpectedly make perfect sense to your students after you accidentally draw the call stack backwards.
The deprecated function you've been warning students about for years will make a surprising comeback in next month's major framework update.
A visiting professor will challenge your views on tabs vs. spaces. Their argument will change the way you think about code readability forever.
Your next coding workshop will inspire a student to create a startup that revolutionizes the way we debug parallel processing.
The error message you've been ignoring in your lecture slides contains the key to improving your department's entire testing methodology.
That complex database schema you sketched on the whiteboard last semester will appear in someone's dissertation defense - but with an elegant improvement you'll wish you'd thought of.
